column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0063] Turning next to FIGS. 7A and 7B, a method of running a single trip with wireline perforating guns and a frac plug or bridge plug will now be described.
#Text=FIGS. 7A and 7B show the downhole tool 100, which serves here as a frac plug, attached to a perforating tool 500, which can also serve as an example of a setting apparatus.
#Text=While this method is being described with reference to downhole tool 100, other downhole tools described herein can be similarly used in place of downhole tool 100.
#Text=[0064] The perforating tool 500 can include components of conventional perforating tools that are well known in the art.
#Text=For example, the perforating tool 500 includes a perforating gun assembly 502 and a rope socket/firing head assembly 504 that are connected to a wireline 506.
#Text=[0065] The downhole tool 100 is attached to the bottom of the perforating tool 500 via a shearable setting adapter 150.
#Text=Other adapters or release tools, including those disclosed herein, can be used to connect the downhole tool 100 to the perforating tool 500.
#Text=This assembly is lowered into a well bore 508 to the desired setting depth.
#Text=The downhole tool 100 is set, for example as described above.
#Text=The perforating tool 500 is separated from the downhole tool 100 by releasing the shearable setting adapter 150 from the downhole tool 100 as described above.
#Text=The well bore 508 may or may not be pressure tested.
#Text=A signal is sent to the perforating gun assembly 502 via the wireline 506 to fire the perforating charges.
#Text=The perforating tool 500 and setting adapter 150 are then removed from the well bore 508.

#Text=This method advantageously eliminates the need for a separate, second electrical pressure-setting charge that prior systems used for sealing the well bore prior to firing the perforating charges.

#Text=Since the presently disclosed method does not require an electric charge for setting a packer or frac plug, the present method also eliminates the need to provide for discrimination between two different charges (e.g., positive and negative charges).
#Text=Such discrimination was required by prior systems in order to prevent the perforating charges from firing before the frac plug is set.
#Text=[0066] Turning next to FIGS. 8A-8F, a downhole tool or frac plug embodiment is shown and generally designated as downhole tool 600.
#Text=The downhole tool 600 has a central opening 602 and a mandrel 604, where the central opening extends longitudinally through the mandrel 604.
#Text=The mandrel 604 is attached to a setting tool 700 via one or more shear pins 652.
#Text=The setting tool 700 serves as an example of a setting apparatus.
#Text=It will be clear to those skilled in the art that the downhole tool 600 is similar to downhole tool 100, but has a few significant differences.
#Text=[0067] Downhole tool 600 comprises a retractable packer cup 606.
#Text=Unlike packer cup 106 of downhole tool 100, packer cup 606 includes a lip sleeve 607.
#Text=The lip sleeve 607 is attached, for example using an adhesive, to a retractable elastomer lip portion 610.
#Text=The retractable elastomer lip portion 610 is retractable in that it is configured to retract from the unset position shown in FIG. 8B to the set position shown in FIG. 8F as described below.
